item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Show an image gallery
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: Show an image gallery
item.content:encoded: JupyterLab and Jupyter Notebook can display HTML-embedded images in notebook documents. You can usethe IPython.display.HTML class to structure these images into a basic image gallery.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Config, data, and runtime paths
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: Config, data, and runtime paths
item.content:encoded: You can get a list of standard paths Jupyter tools use for configuration, static assets, and temporary runtime files by running the command jupyter --paths.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Display handles
item.content:encoded: IPython's display() function can return a DisplayHandle object. You can use a DisplayHandle to update the output of one cell from any other cell in a Jupyter Notebook.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: IPython's ! returns an SList
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: IPython's ! returns an SList
item.content:encoded: IPython shell assignment (the ! operator) evaluates a command using the local shell (e.g., bash) and returns a string list (IPython.utils.text.SList). An SList is a list-like object containing "chunks" of stdout and stderr, properties for accessing those chunks in different forms, and convenience methods for operating on them.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Run a notebook headlessly
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: Run a notebook headlessly
item.content:encoded: You can use nbconvert to execute a notebook from the command line (aka headlessly) and store the results in a new notebook file, an HTML file, a PDF, etc. Tools based on nbconvert, like papermill and nbflow, take this capability a step further and let you easily parameterize and chain notebooks.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Run and say "done!"
item.content:encoded: Many modern web browsers provide a speech synthesis API for JavaScript.You can write and invoke a function to have your notebook speak when it finishes executing certain cells, whether you're running it in JupyterLab (>=0.34) or classic Jupyter Notebook.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Kernels for text files in JupyterLab
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: Kernels for text files in JupyterLab
item.content:encoded: You can associate a Console panel and kernel with a text editor in JupyterLab, and use it to execute selected code, RStudio style.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Launch Notebook on Binder without leaving your browser
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: Launch Notebook on Binder without leaving your browser
item.content:encoded: You can launch a temporary Jupyter Notebook server in the cloud with any pip or conda packaged libraries preinstalled using the GitHub Gist and Binder web UIs.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: Use nbconvert to clear notebook outputs
item.description: Jupyter Tidbit: Use nbconvert to clear notebook outputs
item.content:encoded: nbconvert has a preprocessor that clears cell outputs from notebook files, leaving cell inputs intact.

item.title: Jupyter Tidbit: %run your ipynb file
item.content:encoded: The %run magic provided by IPython not only supports the execution of regular Python scripts, it also runs Jupyter Notebook files (.ipynb).
